items.title: _translate_keys in Transmissions should match API
items.body:
The keys sent to transmissions.send() don't match the SparkPost API documentation. Worse, these mismatched keys aren't documented anywhere, so you have to go into the code to trace down the issue.

For example: `model['campaign_id'] = kwargs.get('campaign')`

It should just use `campaign_id` to match the API.  Better yet, don't qualify the passed data; just send it to the API.

items.title: Unable to set all supported options on transmissions API
items.body:
The options the API allows are not consistent with what the library supports.

e.g.  the API offers   perform_substitutions  as an option, but there is no way to set this in the python call.  (in general the fact that naming and structure is different from the API is somewhat confusing)

Maybe give the option to initialize options yourself in`Transmissions._translate_keys` :
`'options': kwargs.get('options', {})`  
?

items.title: Support for EU accounts in the Django backend.
items.body: There is currently no way to configure the Django backend to use the EU API.

items.title: content.email_rfc822 support
items.body: As per https://developers.sparkpost.com/api/transmissions/#transmissions-post-send-rfc822-content, it should be possible to submit this type of content (as alternative to html & text content).

items.title: from_email long format doesn't seem to handle commas in name (unless name is quoted)
items.body:
This isn't actually your bug, but I thought you might want to document it, or perhaps support an optional explicit `{"name": x, "address": y}` format.

I attempted to specify a `from_email` along the lines of `'Company Name, LLC <address@example.com>'` and got error messages like:

    sparkpost.exceptions.SparkPostAPIException: Call to https://api.sparkpost.com/api/v1/transmissions returned 400, errors:
    Invalid domain Code: 7001 Description: No sending domain specified 

I tracked this down to the `parseaddr` function in Python's `email.utils` module, which is behaving like:

    >>> from email.utils import parseaddr
    >>> parseaddr("Company Name, LLC <address@example.com>")
    ('', 'Company')
    >>> parseaddr("Company Name LLC <address@example.com>")
    ('Company Name LLC', 'address@example.com')

**Updated**: It looks like quoting the name portion can fix this, so it might be sufficient to suggest as much in the documentation. Example:

    >>> parseaddr('"Company Name, LLC" <address@example.com>')
    ('Company Name, LLC', 'address@example.com')

items.title: Receiving frequent ECONNRESET errors
items.body:
We started receiving regular errors appearing to originate from the `python-sparkpost` library when trying to send transmissions.  They fail deep in a dependent library from what appears to be a connection reset, but it's hard to tell. We upgraded everything we could think of to the latest version (New Relic, `requests`, `sparkpost`, `pyopenssl`, `cryptography`) but this is continuing to happen and causing us to frequently drop emails.

We believe at this point this is due to something in the Sparkpost library. Do you have any idea what it might be?

items.title: The `return_path` param shouldn't have a default value
items.body: The `transmission.send` method sets `default@sparkpostmail.com` as the `return_path` param if none is passed. This shouldn't be the case, as return paths are set by the system when not provided - and differ for different regions. This defaulting should be removed.

items.title: Add requests library as dependency
items.body: The library is not working without the `requests` library. Hence, it should be added as dependency.

items.title: List-Unsubscribe header is overwritten for not transactional messages
items.body:
`List-Unsubscribe` header is overwritten when email is not marked `transactional`. 

Value of this header should stay as it is or be modified as [the other unsubscribe links are](https://www.sparkpost.com/docs/user-guide/setting-up-unsubscribe-links/).  

To ensure `List-Unsubscribe` header with a custom unsubscribe link, we need to set `X-MSYS-API` header. Django example:

```python
unsubscribe_link = 'https://example.com/unsubscribe'
message = EmailMultiAlternatives(subject=subject, body=text_message, to=to, **kwargs)
message.extra_headers['List-Unsubscribe'] = "<{}>".format(unsubscribe_link)
message.extra_headers['X-MSYS-API'] = json.dumps({'options': {'transactional': True}})
```
    
I know this may out of scope for this project, but I contacted Sparkpost support with the problem and they kindly put my suggestion on ice. 

@jgzamora maybe you can pitch this issue with the dev team. If not let's it rest here so people can vote on it and know about a workaround.

items.title: Document how to specify alternative base URI
items.body:
This would be helpful for SparkPost Enterprise users. E.g.:

```
sp = SparkPost(api_key='12345678abcdef', base_uri='https://host.name.goes.here')
```

items.title: How do I send a Django email with a custom From header?
SparkPostMessage wrapper for Django EmailMessage ignores extra_headers field
items.body:
I'm trying to set a HTTP version of `List-Unsubscribe` header into a message and it gets dropped during conversion from `EmailMessage.extra_headers` to sparpost `transmissions.send` params, where it should probably land as `custom_headers` (_Used to set any headers associated with transmission_).

Anyway even patching `SparkPostMessage` class and making sure `custom_headers` get posted as `model['content']['headers']` has no effect, HTTP variant of `List-Unsubscribe` header is missing it the message received.

Custom `List-Unsubscribe` is present in the message received only when [transactional](https://developers.sparkpost.com/api/transmissions.html#header-options-attributes) option is set, but then the message lacks a MAILTO variant.

items.title: Attachment Support
items.body: Is there attachment support in this API? I see in the [documentation](https://www.sparkpost.com/docs/user-guide/sending-attachments/), it does say that it supports attachment with the inline template, so I am assuming it might be available, but couldn't locate the documentation readme.

items.title: Document how to use per-recipient substitution data, metadata, etc.
items.body:
The [Transmissions API](https://developers.sparkpost.com/api/transmissions.html) supports substitution data, metadata and tags are the recipient level, but there's no explanation of how to do this in the documentation. Only this text in https://python-sparkpost.readthedocs.io/en/latest/resources/transmissions.html :

> Substitution data can be specified at the template, transmission and recipient levels. The order of precedence is as follows: recipient overrides transmission overrides template.

For reference, substitution data is supported by passing in a dictionary to the send method. E.g.:

```python
response = sp.transmissions.send(
...
  recipients = [
    {
      'address': { 'email': 'recipient@somewhere.example' },
      'substitution_data': { 'name': 'Rachael' }
    }
  ],
...
)
```

The same may work for metadata and tags, but I have not tested that (yet).

I'm using version 1.3.5.

items.title: Test integration with django-anymail
items.body: We want to recommend the use of [django-anymail](https://github.com/anymail/django-anymail) with 2.x. As such we should test the 2.x working branch against it and prepare any necessary PRs.

items.title: Add support for events management
items.body:
Message events are huge part of sparkpost system and api with meny types of events, but this lib missing them totaly. Listing events, searching events ...

Thanks

Pavel Cisar

items.title: reply-to
items.body:
Hi,

I'm using python-sparkpost since a while, but I realized that I can't make reply-to work correctly. It does work if I write it in the template definition (on the website), it does not work if I pass it as argument in the transmission. 

Looking at the code it seems that python-sparkpost correctly puts it in the content array. I'm using it with a template-name referring a template stored on sparkpost.

Any help is appreciated. Thanks in advance
sandro
*:-)

items.title: Remove unnecessary subclasses
items.body:
With 2.0, the only reason to have a subclass would be to create syntactic sugar for things that aren't super easy to do with the raw API. One example is the formatting of email addresses for the transmissions API. For API endpoints that we don't need sugar for, we should remove the subclasses.

* Metrics
* Recipient Lists
* Suppression List
* Templates

items.title: Update Transmissions class
items.body:
Update the Transmission class to use the new base resource with sugar methods.

* Update Transmission subclass of base class
* Add sugar methods
** cc: update payload to include cc
** bcc: update payload to include bcc
* Add translation methods
** Translate short form recipients / from to longer form name + email format

Notes:

* Use as much of existing class makes sense / is possible, paying specific attention to methods that are included to address issues

items.title: Create base resource
items.body:
This ticket is to create the base resource - a class that can be used directly or subclassed to create wrappers with some syntactic sugar.

* User can invoke the base resource to call any API available and pass through any parameters available
* User can invoke any of the supported methods on a given API (SP supports only GET, POST, PUT, DELETE)
* Custom exception class is thrown when an error in the API occurs
* Responses must pass through to user without modification for both success and failure

items.title: Update documentation
items.body:
Update the documentation to reflect the approach for version 2.

* Update Sphinx docs
* Update README
* Update examples
* Add integration documentation - e.g. django-anymail, celery, etc.

items.title: Validate recipients as list or dict
items.body: We currently don't do any input validation for recipients. It'd be pretty simple to check for list or dict and throw an appropriate exception. This will help avoid some confusion around the error received when a string, for example, is passed.

items.title: Django: unable to set campaign when using EmailMessage object
items.body:
I'm trying to send an email with a campaign id using a `EmailMessage` object as follows:

```
msg = EmailMessage(
    subject='Test Campaign',
    to=['test@test.com']
)
msg.template = 'test-template'
msg.substitution_data = substitution_data
msg.campaign = 'test-campaign'
msg.send()
```

Viewing the message in the SparkPost Dashboard, I can see the template and data are set, but the campaign remains empty. Following https://github.com/SparkPost/python-sparkpost/issues/107, it looks like the problem is in the `SparkPostMessage` class. `substitution_data`, `template` are copied there, but not `campaign`.

items.title: TypeError when sending to an umlaut domain
items.body:
One of our older Python 2.7 projects ran into an error when sending a transactional email to a domain containing an umlaut (e.g. "someone@my-umlaut-domäin.com"). Our transmission includes recipient attributes:

```
sp.transmissions.send(
    recipients=[{
        'address': {
            'name': u'Firstname Lastname',
            'email': u'someone@my-umlaut-domäin.com',
        }
    }],
    template='my-template'
)
```

The package version 1.1.1 gave us the following error:
`At least one valid recipient is required`

Updating to the latest release 1.3.2 returned this error:
`TypeError: sequence item 0: expected string, dict found`

Unicode recipients should be supported since package version 1.0.3. Is there something we miss?

items.title: Transmission list method add uri parameters
items.body:
https://developers.sparkpost.com/api/transmissions.html#transmissions-list-get
```python
def list(self, **kwargs):
    """
    Get a list of your transmissions....
    
    :param campaign_id: ID of the campaign
    :param template_id: ID of the template
    """
    results = self.request('GET', self.uri, params=kwargs)
    return results
```

items.title: BCC and CC copies are not reusing substitution data
items.body: Hey guys, with the new 1.3.1 version BCC and CC are working good, but with substitution_data the copies are been sent with no data.

items.title: Investigate using library on Google App Engine
items.body:
As reported by `@timcederman` in our #python channel in community Slack, the library does not appear to work with Google App Engine:

> has anyone succeeded in getting the Python SDK to work for Google App Engine? I'm hitting issues because of the requests library, which seems to be incompatible with using GAE.
> 
> huh, I finally resolved this by downgrading to requests 2.1.0, but now the exception handling in the sparkpost sdk is broken

items.title: SSL Error
items.body:
We switched from using the SMTP to API some time ago and everything was ok. Since a couple of weeks ago we experience a weird issue (before that, everything was ok): we get SSL errors on our servers, even though on our dev machines the messages are sent properly.

The traceback is as follows:

```
line 490, in send
    track_clicks=False
  File \"/home/alexandru/vibetrace4.python2.7.env/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sparkpost/transmissions.py\", line 233, in send
    results = self.request('POST', self.uri, data=json.dumps(payload))
  File \"/home/alexandru/vibetrace4.python2.7.env/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sparkpost/base.py\", line 38, in request
    **kwargs)
  File \"/home/alexandru/vibetrace4.python2.7.env/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sparkpost/base.py\", line 9, in request
    response = requests.request(method, uri, headers=headers, **kwargs)
  File \"/home/alexandru/vibetrace4.python2.7.env/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/requests/api.py\", line 56, in request
    return session.request(method=method, url=url, **kwargs)
  File \"/home/alexandru/vibetrace4.python2.7.env/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/requests/sessions.py\", line 475, in request
    resp = self.send(prep, **send_kwargs)
  File \"/home/alexandru/vibetrace4.python2.7.env/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/requests/sessions.py\", line 596, in send
    r = adapter.send(request, **kwargs)
  File \"/home/alexandru/vibetrace4.python2.7.env/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/requests/adapters.py\", line 497, in send
    raise SSLError(e, request=request)
SSLError: bad handshake: Error([('SSL routines', 'SSL3_GET_SERVER_CERTIFICATE', 'certificate verify failed')],)
", "err_details": "SSLError(SSLError(SSLError(\"bad handshake: Error([('SSL routines', 'SSL3_GET_SERVER_CERTIFICATE', 'certificate verify failed')],)\",),),)
```

The environment has installed the following packages (same on both servers):

```
sparkpost==1.2.0
requests==2.11.1
certifi==2016.8.8
```

The machine that the code does not work on is a Debian 7.11 Wheezy with OpenSSL 1.0.1e.

Not sure how to track the issue and fix this.

Thanks

items.title: Django backend raises KeyError Exception when the API returns an error
items.body: Today the API was returning the error `{u'errors': [{u'message': u'Unable to contact authorization service.'}]}` which causes the Django backend to raise an error because the key total_accepted_recipients was not in the response.  The Django backend should handle API errors more robustly

items.title: missing param 'sources' in suppression list
items.body:
`key_map = {
            'from_date': 'from',
            'to_date': 'to',
            'types': 'types',
            'limit': 'limit',
            'sources': 'sources'
        }`

items.title: Error using cc or bcc with recipients substitution_data
items.body:
At some point in the past couple of weeks, SparkPost started rejecting the cc recipient in the following call:

``` python
from sparkpost import SparkPost
sp = SparkPost()
result = sp.transmissions.send(
    from_email='test@example.com',  # use a valid sender for your account
    recipients=[{
        'address': {'email': 'to@example.com'},
        'substitution_data': {'order_no': '12345'}
    }],
    cc=['cc@example.com'],
    subject='test',
    text='test merge {{ order_no }}'
)
# {'total_rejected_recipients': 1, 'total_accepted_recipients': 1, 'id': '102374996990914834', 'rcpt_to_errors': [{'message': 'invalid data format/type', 'code': '1300', 'description': 'field \'recipients[1].address.header_to\' value \'{ "substitution_data": { "order_no": "12345" }, "address": { "email": "to@example.com" } }\' is of type \'json_object\', but needs to be of type \'string\''}]}
```

The problem seems to be in the payload's `header_to` generated for the `cc`. If you omit the `cc` parameter, it works fine. Similarly, if you change to a simple `recipients=['to@example.com']`, the send is accepted (albeit without the intended substitution data).

This worked (or at least was accepted by the API) on 2016-06-07. I don't believe python-sparkpost has changed during that period. Is this a problem in python-sparkpost, or an intentional API clarification/change? If the latter, is there way to specify substitution_data and cc (or bcc) in the same transmission?

python 3.5 (or 2.7); python-sparkpost 1.2.0

items.title: Problem with sending emails with emojis
items.body:
I got an issue with emails that contain emojis. When I receive email with emojis
all emojies are displayed like a bunch of '??'. I tried to send the same data via Postman
and email I received wasn't broken. So it seems someting wrong happens on the way 
between this python client and API server.
By digging into source code of `Transmissions` part and by sniffing traffic
I found that python's json module encodes (dumps) 'not simple' non-ascii characters 
(such emojies) to '\uXXXX' notation as a surrogate pair (as expected):

```
>>> emoji = u"😄"
>>> emoji
u'\U0001f604'
>>> print json.dumps(emoji)
"\ud83d\ude04"
```

By sending this data I got this emoji looks like:

```
\xed\xa0\xbd\xed\xb8\x84
```

And it's of course wrong. I sniffed traffic between Postman and API server and I found
that Postman sends json in utf-8 (without escaping to \uXXXX):

```
\xf0\x9f\x98\x84
```

So I repeat this in Python and it worked:

```
>>> json.dumps(emoji, ensure_ascii=False).encode('utf-8')
'"\xf0\x9f\x98\x84"'
```

I don't know on what side problem is, but this is my workaround to handle this problem.
And this Issue is just a point on a problem and its possible solution.

PS. There is no problem with sending emails consist of simple chars like '\u2605'.

items.title: Add docs for celery

milestone.description: This milestone will be a major release that includes a significant refactor into a library that has a thin HTTP layer and sugar methods.

items.body: We should point users using celery to django-celery-email - which works with any backend.

items.title: Support additional options in Django email backend
items.body: We recently added some code related to #107 to allow Django users to set `template` and `substitution_data`. It would be nice if we had a simple way to allow other options without having to modify the code, add tests, etc (think `campaign`, click and open tracking, etc.).

items.title: Django backend -unable to use templates and substitution_data
items.body:
While using `EMAIL_BACKEND = 'sparkpost.django.email_backend.SparkPostEmailBackend'` and creating a message like this:

```
 msg = EmailMultiAlternatives(
    to=to_list
  )
  msg.template = template
  msg.substitution_data = substitution_data
```

I've encountered several problem with missing params. After debugging I've found out that template and substitution_data are ignored. becasue they are not considered as a part of SparkPostMessage class. As result `_send(self, message)` in `SparkPostEmailBackend` is also ignoring those params.

If it's not a bug, then please provide an explanation in documentation how to use `SparkPostEmailBackend` and send emails using substitution data and templates.

items.title: Support SparkPost in django-anymail
items.body:
This isn't an issue related directly to this repository, but it seemed like a good place to reach out to the developers at SparkPost on this issue.

With Mandrill now having no free tier, customers are looking to migrate to other ESPs. SparkPost seems like a good candidate, as it has a similar UI to Mandrill, has a generous free tier and a helpful migration tool. The latter is important, because businesses on the free tier probably don't want to spend a lot of time and money on switching.

It therefore makes sense that migrating the backend to SparkPost is easy too. [django-anymail](https://github.com/anymail/django-anymail) has made it easy to migrate from djrill, a package which supported only Mandrill, to its ESP-agnostic interface, making it easy to switch to any one of a number of supported ESPs. However, SparkPost is not currently supported.

This is a shame. With support for SparkPost in django-anymail, it would make it easier still for django users to migrate from Mandrill to SparkPost.

I've made [a request for its support on that repository](https://github.com/anymail/django-anymail/issues/11), but I also thought it would be worth raising it with you here.

items.title: SparkPostAPIException: content.inline_images requires content.html
items.body:
I have a weird issue, preventing me from sending emails out with sparkpost==1.1.0 and Django==1.8.12. I traced the steps, starting with a simple:

```
email = EmailMessage('TEST SUBJECT', 'TEST MSG', 'from@example.com', ['to@example.com'])
email.send()
```

This causes to execute (`.../python2.7/site-packages/sparkpost/transmissions.py", line 232`):

```
results = self.request('POST', self.uri, data=json.dumps(payload))
```

The payload here (as per django_extensions) looks like this:

```
{'description': None, 'recipients': [{'address': {'email': 'to@example.com'}}], 'campaign_id': None, 'return_path': 'default@sparkpostmail.com', 'content': {'from': {'email': 'from@example.com'}, 'attachments': [], 'text': 'TEST MSG', 'headers': {}, 'html': None, 'reply_to': None, 'use_draft_template': False, 'inline_images': [], 'template_id': None, 'subject': 'TEST SUBJECT'}, 'substitution_data': None, 'options': {'skip_suppression': None, 'open_tracking': None, 'start_time': None, 'inline_css': None, 'transactional': None, 'sandbox': None, 'click_tracking': None, 'ip_pool': None}, 'metadata': None}
```

Error returned:

```
SparkPostAPIException: Call to https://api.sparkpost.com/api/v1/transmissions returned 422, errors: required field is missing: content.inline_images requires content.html
```

However, when I substitute `[]` with `None` in payload at this stage, the message goes out.

items.title: Allauth forgot password
items.body:
Using the django allauth package to do my auth.

Clicking the forget password and sending by email, I get below.
No idea how to debug. How do i event add stuff to the content.html?

sparkpost.exceptions.SparkPostAPIException
SparkPostAPIException: Call to https://api.sparkpost.com/api/v1/transmissions returned 422, errors:

```
    required field is missing: content.inline_images requires content.html
```

Using this works
EMAIL_HOST = 'smtp.sparkpostmail.com'
EMAIL_PORT = 587
EMAIL_HOST_USER = 'SMTP_Injection'
EMAIL_HOST_PASSWORD = '348b25528c6b64abc0b423307314292c108d8899'
EMAIL_USE_TLS = True

items.title: Automatically parse long form emails in from field
items.body: When we have an email in the format `Example Person <person@example.com` supplied in the `from_email` we should automatically parse it into the longer form dict `from: { name: 'Example Person', email: 'person@example.com`` format. This gets around some issues related to unicode and how our system parses the long form.

items.title: Preview template returns error
items.body:
When running the following code

```
    sub_data = {'content': html}

    result = sparkpost_client.templates.preview(
        template_id='newsletter',
        substitution_data=sub_data,
        draft=False
    )
```

I get the following error:

```
required field is missing: field 'substitution_data' is required
```

I think it may be because, in templates.py, line 181:

```
data=json.dumps(substitution_data))
```

You can't just simply dump the json, need to append it to a new dict with the "substitution_data" key before doing that.

I'm fairly sure this is the issue because if i change my code like so:

```
    sub_data = {'substitution_data': {'content': html}}

    result = sparkpost_client.templates.preview(
        template_id=config.item['sparkpost_template'],
        substitution_data=sub_data,
        draft=False
    )
```

It works.

items.title: Critical Error on Django Backend
items.body:
I've been two days behind a bug in the Django Backend. 

Some of the text-only emails were arriving in HTML and with the content of other totally different email. Only viewing the email in raw you can see the correct text content.

The problem was the backend was modifing the global settings dict.
#87 should fix this bug.

items.body: Need to change this to say it's a list of dicts.

items.title: Update docs to show from_email formats
items.body:
You can supply a friendly from in the existing `from_email` field. For example the following are both valid:

``` python
sp.transmissions.send(..., from_email='testing@example.com', ...)
```

``` python
sp.transmissions.send(..., from_email='Test Email <testing@example.com>', ...)
```

The `_extract_recipients` (see [this line](https://github.com/SparkPost/python-sparkpost/blob/master/sparkpost/transmissions.py#L99)) method handles converting either of these into the proper format for the API. We just need to document it.

Set up Travis to run in Python 3.5
items.body: We currently have tox tests to run against Python 2.7, 3.4, and 3.5, but Travis only runs against 2.7 and 3.4. Need to look into adding 3.5 to the list of Pythons Travis runs tests against.

items.title: Add tox support
items.body:
[Tox](https://tox.readthedocs.org/en/latest/) is a testing tool that allows local testing of various combination of Python versions and dependencies. It is similar to running the Travis build locally, which can be very helpful as the number of version combinations grows.

I'll make a pull request to demonstrate its usage.

items.title: Docs tweaks

A few items based on some feedback:
- Update docs to show example transmission with substitution data
- Update docs to explain precedence of substitution data - recipient > transmission > template
- Use `transmissions` instead of `transmission`

items.body:
Currently these are not supported. 

Once these are added in the python library, we'll have to add the support those in the upcoming Django backend too.

items.title: API Keys
items.body:
Caveat to this issue: I maybe misreading the code and there is another way to do this that I am not seeing.

While working on the Java SDK I see this project and PHP SDK require the API Key to be set inside a checked in file. [Example](https://github.com/SparkPost/python-sparkpost/blob/master/examples/transmissions/send_transmission.py#L3)

I believe things like that should not be placed inside checked in code because it is too easy to accidentally checkin you key.

I would prefer to see a name something like "config.something.example" that gets checked in. Put "config.something" would be put in the .gitignore so ti is not checked in. The example file would have the place holder properties.

The above filenames should use something appropriate for the language. In Java it would probably be "config.properties.example".

items.title: Map POST/PUT Payloads to the API documentation
items.body:
It is confusing for developers to use a flattened structure of their request payloads, especially when the property names vary from the API documentation on SparkPost.com/api.

Use a idiomatic structure passthrough that maps to the API docs for all first class citizens of the SparkPost API.

items.title: POST to /transmissions using a Campaign ID
items.body:
The REST API Documentation has "campaign_id" listed as the property to use in all the human readable documentation.

Shouldn't the SparkPost Python SDK POST to /transmission use the same property name instead of "campaign" as you can see here:

https://github.com/SparkPost/python-sparkpost/blob/master/examples/transmissions/send_transmission.py#L26

items.title: Receiving mixed response on POST to /transmissions

milestone.title: 1.0.0.dev2
milestone.description: The second developer release. Issue could introduce breaking changes.

items.body:
Using the Python SDK, a POST to /transmissions with the BODY.recipients set to an array of strings, shown in example below, returns a mixed 200 response.

```
recipients = ['user@domain.com', 'anotheruser@anotherdomain.com']
```

Response:

```
{u'total_accepted_recipients': 1, u'id': u'30010207866232273', u'rcpt_to_errors': [{u'message': u'invalid data format/type', u'code': u'1300', u'description': u'address  is not JSON'}], u'total_rejected_recipients': 1}
```

The example code shows this as a valid use case:
https://github.com/SparkPost/python-sparkpost/blob/master/examples/transmissions/send_transmission.py#L7

Need to research if this is a valid bug (and resolve) or user error.

items.title: Unable to install Pre-Release version of SDK
items.body:
Using pip > 1.4.x there is no longer support for pre-release packages (like the SparkPost Python SDK) unless you use the --pre option on the pip command.

Adding this issue from this question on Stackoverflow:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/29871778/sparkpost-python-sdk-install-failing/29871893

Here's the reference I found that helped me resolve this issue:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18230956/could-not-find-a-version-that-satisfies-the-requirement-pytz

Error installing local python-sparkpost package

```
pip install -e <path/to/python-sparkpost/>
```

Here's the output I'm receiving (forgive me if this is simple...my Python hasn't been touched since 1.x versions). It very well could be an environment issue, and I'm going to keep on digging, but I thought I'd share what I hit.

items.title: Transmissions improvements
items.body:
Right now, we have to do the following:

``` python
sp.transmission.create(
    recipients=[{'address': {'email': 'rich.leland@messagesystems.com'}}],
    description='test',
    campaign='rich-testing',
    metadata={},
    substitution_data={},
    reply_to='rich@richleland.com',
    subject='test messsage',
    envelope_from='test@sparkpostbox.com',
    text='test message'
)
```

The recipients part seems especially over-complicated to me. Maybe just allow an array of addrs but also support the more complex object.

Additionally, we should change `envelope_from` to `from` as this field is actually the `From` header (aka Friendly From).
